Description: Fragment of lid of Chian black-figured Sphinx and Lion Style pottery stemmed bowl; white slip; interior reserved; exterior: black-figure decoration consisting of two lions to right (head, underbelly and foreleg remaining of that to left, with added red snout, mane and foreleg; rump with red dot and tail probably of seated lion); short vertical stroke and rosette with red centre as filling ornament; below, two dilute bands above traces of outer frieze.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
Lemos places this sherd in Stage 1 of Group D of the Sphinx and Lion Style. Although the imagery is lively, the execution of the figures is loose and careless.
Bibliographic references: Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 322, no. 1451, pl. 192)
Fairbanks 1928 / Early Vases preceding Athenian Black Figure Ware (p. 103, no. 310.1, pl. XXXII)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.2110) (phase 2)
Robinson 1893 / Catalogue of Greek, Etruscan and Roman Vases (p. 213, no. 23)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.5962 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
